title: What Is the 75-15-10 Rule? The Modern Budgeting Method for a Changing World
description: The 75-15-10 rule is a modern budgeting approach designed for high-cost and fast-changing economies. Learn how this rule works and how to apply it anywhere in the world.

content.text: As living costs rise around the world, many people feel that traditional budgeting methods like the 50/30/20 rule no longer match their financial reality. That’s where the 75-15-10 rule comes in a modern, realistic budgeting system created to help individuals and families survive and thrive in high-cost environments. Whether you live in a major European city, a fast-growing African economy, North America, the Middle East, or Asia, this rule adjusts better to today's global financial challenges.
What Is the 75-15-10 Rule?

The 75-15-10 rule divides your after-tax income into three categories: 75% for needs and living expenses, 15% for savings or investing, and 10% for debt repayment or financial obligations. It’s designed for individuals whose essential costs take up a higher percentage of their income due to inflation, rent spikes, or general economic pressure.
Why the 75-15-10 Rule Exists

Traditional budgets assume that your essential needs can fit into 50% or 60% of your income. But with housing, transportation, and food costs rising globally, that expectation often becomes unrealistic. The 75-15-10 rule acknowledges that many people need more room in the 'needs' category while still maintaining a pathway toward savings and debt management.
Breakdown of the 75-15-10 Rule
1. 75% for Needs and Living Costs

This includes all essential expenses required to maintain your daily life. In many countries, especially urban areas, essentials take up a significant portion of income. The 75% allocation helps make budgeting realistic instead of stressful.
2. 15% for Savings and Investments

Even with rising living costs, savings remain essential. This category helps you build long-term wealth, prepare for emergencies, and work toward financial goals. Whether you're earning in dollars, euros, naira, pounds, yen, or any currency, consistent saving is key.
The amount may feel small at first, but over time, regular savings compound into significant financial growth.
3. 10% for Debt Repayment or Financial Obligations

This final category focuses on reducing debt and building financial freedom. Debt repayment is one of the biggest hurdles to financial stability internationally. By budgeting 10% for additional debt payments, you create steady progress toward becoming debt-free.
If you do not have debt, this 10% can be reassigned to savings, investing, or future goals.

Who Is the 75-15-10 Rule Best For?

items: People living in high-cost cities or countries
Individuals affected by inflation or rising rent
Students or families with large essential expenses
People trying to rebuild financially after hardship

content.text: Advantages of the 75-15-10 Rule

items: ✔ Makes room for essential living costs

content.text: Disadvantages to Consider

items: ❗ Lower savings percentage compared to traditional rules
❗ Can slow financial goal progress for high earners
❗ Not ideal for individuals with very high debt
❗ Requires discipline to keep wants under the needs category

content.text: How to Make the 75-15-10 Rule Work Better for You

items: Track your needs carefully avoid mixing wants with essentials
Increase savings when your income grows
Use budgeting apps to track categories
Review and adjust monthly based on your reality
Increase your income (side hustles, skills, freelance work)

content.text: Final Thoughts

The 75-15-10 rule is a realistic and modern budgeting method that matches the world’s current economic climate. It gives you enough room for essential spending while still pushing you toward savings and financial discipline. If you’re struggling with strict budgeting frameworks or living in a high-cost environment, this method offers balance, flexibility, and stability.
Whether you're a student, worker, family provider, or entrepreneur, the 75-15-10 rule helps you build a sustainable financial lifestyle that grows with you no matter where you live in the world.
